title: Why is Portugal socialist but at the same time capitalist? - Quora

response.answer_text: Portugal is not socialist. It’s governed by a so called socialist party. The economy is capitalist. And guess what, the Socialist Party is voted in and can be voted out, but the reason people vote for them is precisely because they seem to do a good job at managing capitalism. The Portuguese Socialist Party is not revolutionary, doesn’t want to abolish capitalism and in fact is a moderate Social Democratic organization. The idea that a country is socialist because it’s governed by a party that has socialism in its name is as absurd as believing that the United States is democratic only when the Democrats are in charge and a Republic only when the Republicans are in charge, as if names of parties had the magical power to change the entire system.

The answer is simple: Portugal IS NOT socialist! Neither capitalist! Not in the sense of old USSR regimes, anyway. Nor in the sense of US capitalism, anyway You need an update to your definitions: there are a few other concepts like social-democracy or democratic socialism that moves away from authoritarian regimes such as those of old USSR or that of present day Venezuela. And the goal of this philosophy while in government is to provide the population a range of basic services such as health care or education freely or with a significant discount. Similar to the politics developed in Scandinavian countries, before the raise of populism.
